titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. The agitation of my mind, in a great measure disqualified me for that vigorous activity which my present occupation requires— I struggled however to subdue my feelings, and so far succeeded as to write my usual morning’s task— Though I could not acquire the tranquility which is necessary for successful application, I found some relief from the application itself, which by leading my thoughts into another channel, and charm’d pain for a while and anguish. I dined with the Corporation at Mr: Gannett’s, and immediately after dinner went in the Stage into Boston— There I found a letter from Mr: Hellen, with a few lines from my dear wife, written on the 22d: the day of our misfortune, and of course a day before that which I received yesterday; and also one of the day after—the 24th:—when she continued thank Heaven, as well as could be expected— I also received a letter from my Sister Smith at New-York.— I found Mr: Boylston at Boston, and with him went out to Neponset Bridge where we had a meeting of the Directors— Mr: Shaw brought me back to Boston, and part of the way up to Cambridge.— My inaugural Oration is this day published both in a pamphlet, and in the Anthology—

div.p: 2. Heard a Lecture from Dr: Waterhouse at 2. O’Clock this afternoon— There were several ladies here at tea—Mrs: Watson, and Mrs: Brimmer—Lady Temple and her Grand-daughter Miss Winthrop— I wrote to Mrs: Adams, and afterwards took a walk. The Composition of my Lectures occupies all my time; and my progress in them is very slow.— I can obtain not enough for reading.

bibl.author: JQA
bibl.subject: Boylston Professor of Rhetoric and Oratory (1805-1809)

div.p: 3. Heard a Lecture from Dr: Waterhouse at 9 this Morning— Finished the second of my Lectures for the Course— Wrote also a little in the first sketch of the fifth— Heard the Declamation at 2 this afternoon— Ten— The Sophomore Class now commence; and one of them declaimed this day.— The Speakers this day had their pieces by heart much better than those of last week; but none of them appear to have any idea of the first elements of public speaking— In my observations to them I repeated, and press’d upon them the advice I gave them last week; adding some further suggestions respecting the selection of their pieces—recommended to them to think of giving variety to their performances—told them I hoped to see the day when they would discard their prompters, of their own choice, and advised them to let the Speaker always stand alone in the box.— The difficulty is to give them a taste for this exercise, which they now dislike more than any other that is required of them.— One of the Sophomores, to declaim next week, told me he had thoughts of speaking in a gown—for which I commended him— Walk’d in the Evening, and called on President Webber, who informed me the Corporation had consented, in consideration of the peculiar Circumstances, that the Sophomore Class should attend my lectures from the beginning.

4. Independence Day— John’s Birth-day— Dr: Waterhouse went into Boston, where the day was celebrated with great splendor— Two parties—one at Faneuil Hall; the other at Copp’s Hill— Though invited to the first, I had no inclination to attend scenes of Mirth; neither could I conveniently spare the time— I spent the day at home, assiduously writing. Wrote a line to my father, enclosing my wife’s letter of 23. June— Took a long walk in the Evening.

5. I purposed to have gone into Boston this morning having some business to transact there— But the weather was so warm that I did not venture out— Attended a lecture of Dr: Waterhouse; and wrote—not so much however as the regular task I have imposed upon myself— Walk’d to the Bridge at Night.— William Smith brought me this afternoon forty copies of my Orations from the Students.

6. Attended Church the whole day and heard prayers read by Mr: Sewall, a son of Judge Sewall of Marblehead; who also read two Sermons of Sherlock, being two parts of his four Sermons on the comparison between revealed and natural religion.— I spent the rest of the day, in writing an Oration for John Smith my nephew to deliver on taking his degree, at New-York— On the Instability of National Greatness— After a walk this Evening I called and pass’d an hour with Mr: Ware.

bibl.author: JQA
bibl.subject: Boylston Professor of Rhetoric and Oratory (1805-1809)

div.p: 7. Heard a lecture this morning from Dr: Waterhouse— Spent the day as I have usually done; but I find I must change the order of my Studies— I have hitherto since I came to Cambridge devoted my time from breakfast untill dinner, to writing off my lectures, as they are to be delivered, and the afternoon to the first draught— But I find upon experience this last to be much the most toilsome task, and I propose in future to invert the order— Mr: Shaw walk’d up, and called on me this Evening— He brought me a letter from my wife.

8. I changed this day the order of my studies in composition; but found no material good effect from it this day; labouring through the topics I find the subject peculiarly difficult, and am obliged to read so much that I can write but very little— Dined with the Committee of the Corporation and Overseers, who were here on an examination of the Sophomore Class— In the Evening I walk’d, and call’d for an hour at Judge Dana’s.

9. Wrote to my wife this morning, and carried the letter to the Post-Office— I found my morning composition much abridged again— In the afternoon however I finished my third Lecture and began the fourth.— Took a short walk in the Evening—

10. Attended a lecture of Dr: Waterhouse; on the several theories of the Earth—Burnet, Whiston, Woodward and Buffon. In the afternoon I attended a declamation— Ten of the Sophomore Class declaimed for the first time— They have discarded the Prompter; but one of them Campbell, failed of getting through.— In the Evening I was overtaken upon my usual walk, by a thunder-shower.

bibl.author: JQA
bibl.subject: Boylston Professor of Rhetoric and Oratory (1805-1809)

div.p: 11. I enter this day upon my fortieth year.— And I this day commenced my course of Lectures on Rhetoric and Oratory— An undertaking of magnitude and importance, for the proper accomplishment of which, I pray, for patience, perseverance, and that favour from above, without which no human industry can avail; but which without persevering Industry, it is presumption to ask— I have devoted all the time, which I can borrow from the necessary business of life, for seven years if so much of life is granted me, to this object— Of these seven years, one has already elapsed— My progress has been slow, and my own improvement, upon which is to depend much of the improvement of others, has been very small— Yet, the beginning is now made, and its success is not without encouragement— My lecture was well received, and could I hope that the issue of the whole course would but bear a proportion to the effect of this introduction, I should be fully satisfied— Few persons except the Scholars (the three Senior Classes) attended— Mr: Randall dined here— Shaw was up from Boston— Heard this morning a lecture from Dr: W.

12. Heard a Lecture this morning from Dr: Waterhouse; and afterwards walked into Boston, with the intention of going out to Quincy, in the Stage. While in Boston, I nearly brought to a close, a transaction, which has been nearly two months in completing— Andrew Dexter junior, for a Company, who have some project on foot has purchased my house in Half-Court-Square— The terms were that they should give me fifteen thousand dollars, payable in instalments of five thousand dollars a year with interest; for which Dexter was to give me notes with two indorsers, and a mortgage of the place itself. I soon after agreed with Mr: John Lowell to purchase of him two houses built on one spot—in Nassau-Street; for which I was to give him the same sum, and payable at the same times, that I was to receive from Dexter— Finally Mr: Lowell agreed to give me the conveyance of his houses completed, and to take the Securities, which I was to receive from Dexter, in payment; an arrangement more suitable to me, as it finished the whole business, without any necessity to me, either of giving, or receiving credit. Various circumstances had delayed the execution of the conveyances untill this day, though all the terms had been agreed upon some weeks since— Among the occasions of delay was, that I had been obliged to send to Washington, to get my deed to Dexter executed and acknowledged by my wife, for her renunciation of dower, and Mr: Lowell had also been obliged to send to Philadelphia to get a deed executed by Mr: Samuel Breck, and his wife, to complete a formality wanting in his title— This day, I executed the deed of my house in Half-Court-Square to Dexter— Dexter executed the mortgage, and gave the notes, endorsed by Alanson Tucker, to Mr: Lowell (who had consented to take notes with one endorser) and Mr: Lowell delivered the deed of his two houses in fee to me. We made a settlement also respecting the rents due— That from Delille my tenant runs from 1. June at $900 a year. Mr: Lowell’s houses are rented—one to H. Gardner, a quarter payable the 15th: of this month—and the other to Joseph N. Bradford, running from 17. June—at $500 a year each— We deducted then from the amount of Rents this day due on both Mr: Lowell’s houses, the amount of the rent this day due by Delille— I paid Mr: Lowell the balance, and I am to receive the current rents on my purchase and Mr: Lowell on his.— The deed of Mr: Lowell to me had been duly signed and sealed, but not acknowledged before a Justice of Peace, by Mrs: Lowell— This formality is indeed very generally omitted in our conveyances here; but I always chuse to have it regularly done— Mr: Lowell therefore took the deed with him to have the acknowledgement of his wife, taken upon it.— This business being thus far accomplished, I saw Genl: Jackson, and agreed with him on the securities to be taken, for payment of the Judgment, which the Assignees of Robert Bird have against him— But not finding Mr: Hall, who is to draw the papers, was obliged to postpone it, for the present.— I dined at Whitcomb’s; and waited from 4. O’Clock P.M. untill past 6. for the Quincy Stage to call for me. It went off however without me; and having but the alternative of returning to Cambridge, or walking to Quincy, I determined on the latter and walked out— I stop’d at Mr: Foster’s shop; and received the last dividend upon my Neponset Bridge Shares— From thence to my father’s house, it took me precisely two hours and twenty-five minutes.

13. Heard Mr: Whitney, both parts of the day— Wrote to Mrs: Adams— In the afternoon I went to my own house, and selected a number of books, which I much want at Cambridge— But the Stage having come away without bringing my trunk, I cannot take them with me to-morrow— Called at Mr: Cranch’s on my return this Evening.

14. Mr: Shaw, and myself went into Boston this morning in the Stage— I called on Mr: H. Gardner, and received of him the rent due on the house, which he occupies— It would be payable to-morrow— I called also upon Mr: Lowell, for the transfer to me of the Policy, by which the houses are insured against fire— He agreed to make the transfer, but not having the policy with him, he is to leave it at the Office—(The Mutual fire Insurance)— I likewise saw Mr: Hall, who is to draw up the papers to be executed by Genl: Jackson; but I could not wait to have them finished this day— I came to Cambridge in the Stage; which started from the Old-State-House at 12. O’Clock.— After dinner, at 2. I attended a lecture of Dr: Waterhouse— Spent the remainder of the afternoon, in writing, part of my fourth lecture— But I found myself so weary, and dull that my composition partook of my feelings— Took my usual walk, at the dusk of the Evening.

15— Spent the whole of this day in my chamber; but in the morning I was employed upon my account Book, and Journal; and in the afternoon wrote with so much difficulty that I did not finish my fourth lecture— Called at President Webber’s this Evening, to enquire, respecting the place, where I am to hear the rehearsals of the performers at Commencement, and at the exhibitions— Determined upon the Meeting-House (if it can be obtained) for the first, and the chapel for the last. Thunder-Shower this Afternoon.

16. Heard a Lecture of Dr: Waterhouse, at 2. this afternoon, on fossils and minerals— Remainder of the day, reading and writing—very slowly— Finished my fourth and began my fifth lecture.— Began the sketch of the sixth.— Spent the Evening at Mr: Benjamin Lee’s, with Dr: Waterhouse and his family.— Reading Murphy’s life of Garrick.

17. Attended a declamation at 2 this afternoon— The performance the most indifferent we have had yet— But Campbell undertook his declamation, and succeeded very well. Mr: Laurie and Dr: Kirkland were here this afternoon— And also Mr: Sargent of Philadelphia, Mr: I. P. Davis and Mr: Shaw— Mrs: Guild and other Ladies below— Walk in the Evening, and called upon Mr: J. L. Austin, to enquire respecting the houses he is building— They will not be finished untill the winter— My writing lags very improperly.

bibl.subject: Boylston Professor of Rhetoric and Oratory (1805-1809)

div.p: 18. Attended this morning a lecture of Dr: Waterhouse, upon Minerals— I was called out from it by Mr: Hall and Genl: Jackson, who came to execute the deed of Jackson’s lots, to secure the payment of the Judgment in favour of Robert Bird’s Assignees— The deed is absolute to me, but the Judgment still remains— And if the money is not paid within one year from the time, when the Judgment was obtained I am to sell, as much of the lots as will satisfy the Judgment, with interest and charges— If the money is paid I am to reconvey to Jackson— The wharf lot, on payment of one third— And either of the Common-Lots on payment of one fourth— The deed was accordingly executed here— But they took it to Boston for acknowledgment. Dr: Randall breakfasted and dined here— At 2. in the afternoon I delivered my second Lecture— The novelty of the subject still keeps up attention, and the dry didactic parts do not yet come on— There were about half a dozen Auditors, besides the Students and College Officers— Shaw was here— And Mr: Boylston and Judge Davis came in before I got through— They came afterwards and spent half an hour with us— I Pass’d the Evening with Dr: Waterhouse, and the family at Mr: Ware’s.

19. Attended a Lecture of Dr: Waterhouse this morning; upon the gradation in the scale of beings— Remainder of the forenoon employed on the first sketch of a Lecture— In the afternoon I went with Dr: Waterhouse to Quincy— He stop’d at Dr: Holbrook’s in Milton, and then proceeded to Mr: A. Baxter’s, where he stop’d— I walk’d thence to my father’s—

20. Heard Mr: Pearce of Brookline— Received a letter from Mrs: Adams which I answered— Dr: Waterhouse, and Mr: Pearce dined with us— I called for the Dr: at Mr: Baxter’s, and we returned this Evening to Cambridge.

21. Lecture from Dr: Waterhouse, on the natural History of Man— Called at the Post-Office, and received the letter from Mrs: Adams, which has lain there several days, waiting for me— At Mr: Gannett’s to enquire, whether Mr: Pearson’s house is to be let— Spent all the rest of the morning; and great part of the afternoon, reading Heron’s Junius; by which I failed entirely my usual morning’s task of writing— Such is forever the character of my application—ready to do any thing, but what I ought to be doing— I went through my afternoon’s task, but necessarily hurried it too much. Walk’d in the Evening to West-Boston Bridge; and on my return, called upon Mr: Holmes.

22. Redeemed in part the waste of Time yesterday morning, by writing more than my ordinary task this forenoon— Heard a public Lecture from Mr: Ware at 2.— On the Benevolence of the Deity.— Walking this Evening I met Mr: English, and apologized to him for declining his invitation to dinner next Saturday— Mr: Ware, Mr: Webster, and Mr: Carey, Resident graduates were at the Drs: in the Evening.

23. Though I devoted this day entirely to my proper business, and lost no time—yet I wrote in the forenoon very little— It was absorbed in examining Aristotle, Quinctilian, and Vossius, on the State of the Controversy— At two, attended a lecture of Dr: Waterhouse—Anatomy of Man. Afternoon, finished my fifth and commenced my sixth Lecture— Mr: Shaw, and Mr: P. Thacher were here this Evening.

24. I went to Boston this morning in the Stage— Wrote to Mrs: Adams, and delivered the letter at the Post-Office— Attended at an Auction of Books—(Mr: Tudor’s) and made some purchases for the library of Congress— Was obliged to leave the House at noon, and after calling at the Mutual Fire Insurance Office for my policies, which were not ready, I returned in the Stage to Cambridge. Mr: Ware also came in the Stage— I was obliged to return to attend the Declamation at 2 O’Clock.— The performance was better than any we have hitherto had.— By the necessity of going to Boston I lost my forenoon task— But I accomplished that of the afternoon— Long walk in the Evening— The Dr: and Mrs: W. pass’d the day at Boston.

Recreation

div.p: 25. Heard a Lecture from Dr: Waterhouse this morning, at 9.— Voltaire’s remarks on the Systeme de la Nature. At 2. in the afternoon, I gave my third lecture— Remainder of the day, employed upon my proper duty— Bathed in the River this Evening— Shaw was again at my lecture— Dr: Craigie— Mr: Hare of Philadelphia— Mr: Emerson & Dr: Howard— Some of the freshmen, asked my permission to attend; but I could not authorize them; and referr’d them to the President.

26. Heard Dr: Waterhouse’s concluding lecture of his Course upon Natural History— It was upon the application of physical Science to the moral purposes of life— With extracts from Soame Jenyns— Judge Dana called upon me; and left a Card for my father— I dined at Mr: T. English’s, at Little Cambridge. Mr: Ware, Mr: Hedge, Mr: Nichols and Mr: Farrar were there— Mr: G. Parsons, Mr: Craig & Mr: G. Bethune were also of the Company— I walk’d there— But Mr: Hedge and Mr: Ware gave me a seat part of the way, and Mr: Craig took me home in the Evening. Mr: S. Hutchinson here to spend a couple of days—

27. Heard a Mr: Chickering of Exeter this morning at Meeting, and Mr: Sewall this afternoon at Church— The forenoon Sermon was on the influence of example, a subject which might have been better managed— The afternoon discourse on the text “thy will be done.”—divided into the reasonableness—the necessity, and the advantage of submission to Providence— I employed all the leisure of the day, upon the draught of a paper important to myself and my family— Walk’d to Cambridge-Port in the Evening— Met and Rode with Mr: Davenport— Mr: Randall was here this Morning; and told us that a Son of Mr H. G. Otis was drown’d last Evening; bathing near his father’s house— I was deeply affected by this melancholy incident; and with the natural feelings of compassion at the distress of the parents see in it a warning of the frail tenure of all human enjoyments.

28. Mr: Hutchinson returned to Boston this Morning— Dr: Waterhouse also went into Boston, and brought me back a letter from Mrs: A. whom I now expect here in four or five days.— I wrote to her, and determined upon consideration of all circumstances, to go into my House at Quincy again for the remainder of the Summer— Enclosed the letter to John Smith at New-York, and carried it to the Post-Office— Mr: Gannett called on me respecting Mr: Pearson’s house which is about to be sold— I spent the day duely attentive to my present proper business.

bibl.subject: Boylston Professor of Rhetoric and Oratory (1805-1809)

div.p: 29. Whole day engaged upon my business— Began in the morning the first draught of my 7th: Lecture, and finished in the afternoon the fair copy of the sixth— I am now prepared for my duties untill Commencement— Wrote to my Mother— Called on President Webber to request that such an arrangement may be made as will enable me to give my Lecture, and hear the declamations on the same day.— Met Mr: Shaw, who had come up from Boston, and walk’d with him. Called also this Evening upon Mr: Ware—

30. I dallied with miscellaneous reading all this forenoon, so much that I lost the greatest part of my morning task— The afternoon also I wrote slower than usual; but eventually performed my usual toil— I began the fair copy of my 7th: Lecture, with which I propose to begin the Series after Commencement— Walk’d in the Evening, though the day has been cold with an incessant mist, never amounting to Rain— The drought is very severe, as almost always happens at this Season of the year— The check upon vegetation is however earlier and greater than has been, any year since my last return from Europe.

bibl.author: JQA
bibl.subject: Boylston Professor of Rhetoric and Oratory (1805-1809)

div.p: 31. So large a portion of my time in the forenoon was engaged in reading, upon the Subject I am now treating, that I had very little left to write, and fell short of my usual task again— Indeed I find it impossible regularly to get through any certain quantity of writing, of my first sketches— Sometimes I write with facility and sometimes with difficulty. When I have much to read I can write little or nothing— J. G. Vossius employed me this morning— Blair speaks of him contemptuously, but I think unjustly. His work I think a very valuable one; and his method very good— At 2. afternoon I heard the declamation; which was better than even that of last week— I got through my afternoon’s task with some difficulty. Called on President Webber twice this Evening, to enquire whether the College Government had determined upon my request to have my two exercises on the same day, weekly— They had not.

Day. Rise between 6 and 7. in the morning— Read two or three chapters in the Greek Testament and as many, in the English Bible— Breakfast between 8 and 9— Pass the forenoon in reading, and composing the first draughts of my Lectures; untill dinner—at half past one— Afternoon writing three pages, fair copy of my Lectures— This employs me untill dark— Then walk an hour or an hour and a half, which brings me to 9 or 10— Sup— And too often sit up reading untill Midnight— This course of occupation has been very regular during my short Residence here; and excepting the Night reading is the most propitious to the composition of my course of Lectures, which I could possibly pursue— In this manner I have completed six Lectures, and got about half through the seventh— But this I must now break up, for I can no longer live separated from my family— My only interruptions have been an hour from 2 to 3. On Thursdays to preside at the Declamations— The same hour on Fridays to deliver my lectures, and occasional attendance on Dr: Waterhouse’s Lectures upon Natural History, while they continued—together with once attending on a public Lecture of Mr: Ware— From Saturday untill Monday I have several Times indulged myself with a visit to my children and my Parents at Quincy.— In the steady application to my new duties I have found the Time gliding rapidly away, and my situation has been perfectly agreeable in the family where I reside.
